title.narrative: 3.7 CP-ADOLESCENT PARTICIPATION

description.narrative: 103/007 By 2020, adolescent boys and girls from selected communities are engaged to develop capacities as agents of change and facilitate action to eliminate harmful social norms and practices with a focus on ending child marriage. CP, which contributes to Access To Justice, Adolescent Empowerment, Adolescents And Hiv/Aids, Child Protection Systems, Child Protection â€“ General, Child Protection â€“ Strengthen Families And Communities, Cross-Sectoral Communication For Development, Cross-Sectoral Monitoring, Data And Situation Analyses, Harmful Practices (Fgm/C And Child Marriage), Hiv Prevention, Human Rights Institutions, Other Cross-Sectoral Programme Areas, Policy Advocacy â€“ Urban, Civil Society, Parliament, Environment, Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children, Social Protection, Treatment And Care Of Children Living With Hiv, Violence, Exploitation And Abuse. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Evaluations, Research And Data, Harnessing Power Of Business And Markets, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: 3. By 2020, adolescent girls and boys in Bangladesh, especially the most disadvantaged, access and utilize high-quality basic social services in a safe and protected environment, and are resilient and empowered as active agents of change.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: 103/007 By 2020, adolescent boys and girls from selected communities are engaged to develop capacities as agents of change andfacilitate action to eliminate harmful social norms and practices with a focus on ending child marriage. CP

description.narrative: UNICEF and the Ministry of Women and Children Affairs (MoWCA) are leading the adoption of strategies to reform the implementation modality of programmes in 7,000 adolescent clubs nationwide towards more sustainability and scalability. In this new strategic direction, interventions will be mostly led by MoWCA through two departments: the Department of Women Affairs and Bangladesh Shihu Academy. As a result of this shift, 49,325 adolescents (70 per cent girls) completed life skills-based education (LSBE) sessions in more than 900 clubs run by MoWCA. Moreover, 218,125 adolescents received training on online safety. | Status:Met | As-of Date:23/12/2021
